## Introduction

I stumbled on the Rationally Speaking Podcast with Julia Galef in 2020, and it was a ray of sunshine in what was then a dark time for me intellectually.

For the first time in the longest time since I can remember, I was consuming a media source in which someone -- in this case, host Julia Galef -- was asking the sort of questions I would ask, making similar comments and criticisms to those I would make, and framing discussion in ways that I would frame. It would be fair to say that it has become my favorite podcast.

It seems like the podcast is either on break or finished,[^break] so I have been going through some of the back catalog. Recently, I listened to two episodes back-to-back that were on a similar subject: [Episode 229](http://rationallyspeakingpodcast.org/229-erisology-the-study-of-disagreement-john-nerst/) "Erisology, the study of disagreement (John Nerst)" and [Episode 244](http://rationallyspeakingpodcast.org/244-seeing-other-perspectives-with-compassion-stephanie-lepp-buster-benson/) "Seeing other perspectives, with compassion Stephanie Lepp & Buster Benson)".

[^break]: Apparently, the podcast has taken extended breaks in the past, for instance, when host Julia Galef focused on working on her book.

Listening to these episodes back-to-back was a bit self-referential because they were about a topic &ndash; disagreement &ndash; that the podcast itself does unusually well.
